MainHeading.P: Chuaigh an Ceann Comhairle i gceannas ar 2.30 p.m.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - Divorce Discussions.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach if it is his intention to hold discussions with representatives of the Churches regarding the possibility of removing the constitutional ban on divorce and introducing divorce legislation; when any such discussions are likely to be held; the purpose of any such discussions; if he intends to consult with any other groups or organisations on this matter; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I have written to the principal Churches, namely, the Roman Catholic, Church of Ireland, Presbyterian, Methodist, the Jewish Congregation and the Society of Friends, proposing consultations during March on action to be taken on the range of matters arising from the report of the Oireachtas Joint Committee on Marriage Breakdown. It is my intention, following these consultations, to bring proposals to Government. The necessity for such consultations is, I believe, self-evident in view of the role of Churches in the solemnisation of marriage. The question of meeting organisations who do not have this function does not arise. All such organisations have already had the opportunity of presenting their views to the joint committee on the issues covered by their terms of reference.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: Does the Taoiseach not agree that the opportunity already afforded the Churches, which was taken up by a number of them including the Presbyterian Church of Ireland and the Church of Ireland, was an adequate form of consultation, and that he should now proceed to legislate on the issue of divorce?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I do not agree. Various bodies, including some of the Churches, made submissions to the committee. The all-party committee have now produced a report which made recommendations. A number of these recommendations impinge directly on the question of marriage and others relate to it. The implementation of these recommendations requires consultation with the Churches which are responsible for the solemnisation of marriage in 99 per cent of cases in this country. Such issues as the minimum age of marriage, the possible desirability of providing for a minimal period of notice before marriage, the enforcement of the law in relation to bigamy and possible changes in the laws relating to marriage and possible remarriage in cases where a marriage has irretrievably broken down directly affect Churches which have the responsibility for solemnising a marriage in 99 per cent of cases. It would be quite improper to proceed to change the law in which the Churches are directly involved under the existing common and statutory law without seeking their views on these matters. There are other matters on which their views could be usefully sought, such as counselling of married couples with matrimonial difficulties, the legal grounds for separation a mensa et thoro, and other matters which may be of indirect interest and where the views of the Churches would be useful before proceeding to make decisions involving the implementation of the recommendations in the report.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: For the benefit of the Members I would point out that the sound amplification system is not working and perhaps Members would bear that in mind.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: Have either the Taoiseach or the Government placed a timescale on the completion of consultations about which he spoke? The Taoiseach referred to a request to the Churches to meet him in March. Could the Taoiseach say whether or not he expects these consultations to be completed in March and what timescale he than proposes for proceeding with legislation arising from those consultations.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I hope to have these consultations during March with a view to reaching conclusions with regard to the implementation of recommendations in the report and to start the process of bringing the proposals to Government as soon as possible after that. That is the clear purpose and intent of the procedures set out.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Question No. 2.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bell Mr. Bell
Speaker.P: In view of the fact that the views of the Labour Party have been known for a considerable time, would the Taoiseach agree that he has had sufficient time to consult with the Churches in order to afford himself and his party an opportunity to support the Labour Party Bill next week?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I sought advice in respect of the matters to be raised and the issues involved and on receipt of that advice I wrote to the Churches. The procedure of examining the report and seeking advice on the relevant issues and approaching the Churches promptly to seek their views is the correct procedure in a matter that intimately links Church and State. I make a clear distinction between a matter of this kind in which Church and State are so closely involved in the same action of solemnising a marriage and other areas in which the Churches may have views which they wish to give but where it would not be necessarily appropriate for the Government to seek their views before acting in a certain way.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - Dífhostaíocht Ghaeltacht Thír Chonaill.
MainHeading.P: 2. D'fhiafraígh

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta cad atá á dhéanamh ag Údarás na Gaeltachta chun laghdú a dhéanamh ar an fhadhb mhór dífhostaíochta i nGaeltacht Thír Chonaill.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Tuigim ó Údarás na Gaeltachta go mbíonn gach dícheall á dhéanamh acu chun tionscnaimh fhiúntacha a aimsiú a chuirfidh deiseanna fostaíochta breise ar fáil i nGaeltacht Dhún na nGall agus sa Ghaeltacht i gcoitinne. Mar thoradh ar na hiarrachtaí sin, bhí 1,937 nduine fostaithe go lánaimseartha ar 31 Nollaig 1984 i dtionscail sa chontae a fuair cúnamh ó Ghaeltarra Éireann/ón Udarás i gcomparáid le 1,508 ar 31 Nollaig 1980.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Conaghan Mr. Conaghan
Speaker.P: An nglacann an tAire go bhfuil daoine sa Ghaeltacht nach bhfuil obair le fáil acu agus go bhfuil dífhostaíocht níos airde san Ghaeltacht agus an gceapann sé go bhfuil gá le deontais níos áirde sa Ghaeltacht chun tionsclóirí a mhealladh isteach, mar a bhí le blianta roimhe seo?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Tá mé cinnte dá mbeadh deontais níos mó le fáil sa Ghaeltacht go meallfaí níos mó daoine isteach chun tionscail a chur ar bun. Is ceist airgid í sin. Ní dóigh liom gur féidir linn é sin a dhéanamh ar an bpointe seo. Ba mhaith liom a rá go bhfuil fostaíocht árd sa Ghaeltacht, níos áirde ná in áiteanna eile. Bhí ardú ar fhostaíocht sa Ghaeltacht ó 1,058 go 1,937 i rith treimhse ceithre bliana.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: An nglacann an tAire go bhfuil árdu ar líon na ndaoine sa Ghaeltacht go dtí an lá atá inniu ann agus an bhfuil an t-árdú fostaíochta dá réir sin?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Tá an-árdú i bhfostaíocht le tréimhse ceithre bliana. Tá sé beagnach 25 faoin gcéad. Glacfaidh an Teachta go bhfuil sé sin níos áirde ná in áiteanna eile. Tá árdú tagaithe ar líon na ndaoine sa Ghaeltacht le cúpla bliain. Tá an ráta fostaíochta ard i gcomparáid le áiteanna eile. Tá fadhb ann le réiteach. Caithfhidh an tÚdarás cloí leis an obair agus feabhas a chur ar an scéal agus beidh tacaíocht le fáil uaimse agus ón Roinn.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: An féidir leis an Aire a thuilleadh tacaíochta a thabhairt do na daoine chun fostaíocht a chur ar fáil nuair atá laghdú ar an gcuid airgid atá a fháil leis an obair sin a dhéanamh? Rud eile dhe, an nglacann sé go bhfuil gearradh siar ar dheontais chun seirbhísí a chur ar fáil le blianta beaga anuas? An nglacann sé gurb í an Ghaeltacht an áit is mó atá ardú ag teastáil i láthair na huaire?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Ní dóigh liom gur gearradh siar airgead don obair atá á déanamh ag an Údarás. Tá ag eirí go maith leo. Ní dóigh liom go bhfuil sé ceart a rá nach mbeadh tacaíocht an Údaráis agus tacaíocht na Roinne le fáil.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: Nach bhfuil sé fíor a rá go bhfuil an tAire ag gearradh siar in áiteanna a raibh deontais faoi leith le fáil acu?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Tá a fhios agam go bhfuil ardú ar an méid a bhí le fáil. Bhí tráth ann nuair nach raibh seirbhísí le fáil sa Ghaeltacht. Is é an polasaí a bhí ag an Roinn agus ag Gaeltarra Éireann nach bhféadfaí deontais a chur ar fáil go dtí go mbeadh na seirbhísí ar fáil. Tá mé ag breathnú ar an chaoi is fearr le deontais a chaitheamh ar sheirbhísí atá ar ceal sa Ghaeltacht agus go bhfuil gá leo.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: An bhfuil sé ar chumas an Aire a insint dúinn an méid deontas a chaitheadh sa Ghaeltacht agus go mór mhór i nGleann Cholm Cille.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Tá faitíos orm nach bhfuil an t-eolas sin ar fáil. Nil agam ach figiúrí don chontae. D'fhéadfhainn an t-eolas a chur ar fáil don Teachta.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: An nglacann an tAire gur gá airgead a chur ar fáil chun tionsclóirí a mhealladh isteach? An bhfuil se sásta athbhreithniú a dhéanamh?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Mar tá a fhios ag an Teachta, chun daoine breise a mhealladh isteach rinneadh an-iarracht sa Ghaeltacht agus sa Ghalltacht. Nílim ag rá go bhfuil deontais ag dul i méid ag an bpointe seo.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - Obair Thithíochta sa Ghaeltacht.
MainHeading.P: 3. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta an bhfuil sé i gceist go mbeadh na rialacha a bhaineas anois le tógáil agus le deisiú tithe i.e. go n-ainmneofaí an conraitheoir a bheas ag déanamh na hoibre, á gcur i bhfeidhm ag an Aire in obair tithíochta a bheas ar siúl ins na Gaeltachtaí.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Is gá, ó 1 Nollaig 1985 ar aghaidh, uimhreacha cánach na gconraitheoirí a dhéanfaidh na hoibreacha a thabhairt sula bhféadfar glacadh le hiarratas ar chúnamh le haghaidh oibreacha feabhsúcháin faoi Achtanna na dTithe (Gaeltacht).
Cé nach mbaineann an coinníoll sin le tithe nua faoi láthair tá i gceist fógra faoi sin a chur amach go luath.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: An nglacann an tAire go bhfuil deacrachtaí ag muintir na Gaeltachta tithe a thógáil ó cuireadh an riail sin i bhfeidhm? Cuireann sé isteach ar mhuintir na n-oileán go gcaithfidh an conraitheoir a bheadh ag déanamh na hoibre a ainmniú.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Tá súil agam nach bhfuil an Teachta ag cáineadh go ndearnadh é sin maidir le tithe nua. Nílim ag cur isteach ar an scéal. Tá cúis mhaith leis. Tá fadhbanna ann.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: Ní féidir le daoine sna hoileáin tithe a thógáil nuair nach mbeadh duine ar bith cláraithe mar chonraitheoir, agus muna mbeidh an obair seo le fáil acu ní bheidh aon obair le fáil acu. Cén chaoi a d'fhéadfá tithe a thógail ar oileán má chuirtear an riail sin i bhfeidhm?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Tá a fhios agam go bhfuil deacrachtaí ann maidir leis sin. Is féidir leis an Teachta bheith cinnte go bhfuil cúis leis an riail sin. Níl an Teachta ag rá nach féidir le daoine ón mhor-thír tithe a fheabhsú agus a thógáil? Níl aon fath nach ndéanfaidís.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: Tá áiteanna iargúlta taobh amuigh de na hoileáin. Tá a fhios ag an Aire go bhfuil go leor daoine san Ghaeltacht agus ar na hoileáin agus nach mbeidh siad ábalta feabhas a chur ar a dtithe. Glacaim leis an gcúis atá leis an riail, ach muna bhfuil siad ábalta an job a dhéanamh iad féin ba cheart eisceacht a dhéanamh.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Rinneadh scrúdú ar an gceist. Má tá an Teachta ábalta mise a shásamh gur féidir leis scéim a chur ar fáil maidir leis na daoine sin agus gur féidir é a chur i gcrích, tá mé sásta athbhreithniú a dhéanamh.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: An nglacann an tAire go bhfuil na daoine atá i gceist againn ábalta dul ar aghaidh le tógáil nó le feabhsú tithe? Sílim go bhfuil a fhios ag an Aire go mbaineann sé le áiteanna iargúlta agus go mba cheart eisceacht a dhéanamh.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Glacaim go bhfuil fadhb ann ach tá fadhb le heisceachtaí chomh maith. Scriosfá an scéim ar fad dá ndéanfá eisceachtaí ar bhealach faoi leith. Mar a dúirt mé cheana, scrúdaíodh an cheist seo agus ní rabhthas in ann teacht ar scéim go bhféadfaí a chur i gcrích gan aon trioblóid a bheith léi.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - Fostaíocht sa Ghaeltacht.
MainHeading.P: 4. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Moynihan Mr. D. Moynihan
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta ó tharla go bhfuil méadú mór tagtha ar uimhir na ndaoine atá anois ag fágáil na Gaeltachta cheal oibre an inseoidh sé cén plean atá ag an Rialtas leis an tuile seo a chosc.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Bíonn iarrachtaí leanúnacha ar siúl ag Údarás na Gaeltachta d'fhonn fostaíocht shocrach a chur ar fáil do mhuintir na Gaeltachta ina gceantair féin agus mar thoradh ar an obair sin bhí 4,405 dhuine fostaithe go lánaimseartha i dtionscail a fuair cúnamh ó Ghaeltarra Éireann/ón Údarás ar 31 Nollaig 1984 i gcomparáid le 4,053 dhuine ar 31 Nollaig 1980. Measann an tÚdarás go léireoidh na figiúirí do 31 Nollaig 1985 méadú breise ar an bhfostaíocht ar an dáta sin.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: An nglacfaidh an tAire leis go bhfuil na Gaeltachtaí ag dul chun deireadh go mór de bharr easpa fostaíochta agus de bharr an chaoi ina bhfuil an Rialtas ag caitheamh leis na Gaeltachtaí i láthair na huaire ó thaobh íocaíocht leasa shóisialaigh agus a leithéidí sin, go bhfuil an imirce ag teacht ar ais arís agus go bhfuil an t-aos óg oilte ag dul thar sáile agus gur caillteanas é sin don Ghaeltacht, don tír agus go mór mhór don teanga agus go bhfeicimid, de réir mar atá cúrsaí ag dul ar aghaidh i láthair na huaire, na Gaeltachtaí ag dul i léig in aghaidh an lae? Cén polasaí atá ag an Aire le cuidiú le muintir na Gaeltachta fanacht ina n-áiteanna féin agus a gcoinneáil sa bhaile?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Ní ghlacaim leis nach bhfuil dul chun cinn á dhéanamh maidir le fostaíocht sa Ghaeltacht. Bhí ardú ar fhostaíocht sa Ghaeltacht le tréimhse bliana nuair a bhí cúlú ar fhostaíocht go ginearálta sa tír. Tá méadú suntasach le feiceáil trí iarrachtaí an Údaráis cé go bhfuil a lán deacrachtaí mar atá a fhios ag an Teachta maidir le fostaíocht sa Ghaeltacht. Tá méadú mar sin féin ó 1984 go 1985 de 200; Ó 1982 go 1983 tá méadú de 85. Sin net figiúirí mar adearfá. Ní dóigh liom gur féidir a rá nach bhfuil dul chun cinn á dhéanamh maidir le fostaíocht. Glacaim go bhfuil daoine óga oilte ann agus go bhfuil sár-oideachas acu ach táimíd anois ag breathnú ar rudaí cosúil le achmhainní nádúrtha agus, tá an-dul chun cinn déanta le déanaí maidir le feirmeoireacht éisc agus tá áit do chéimithe ollscoile go bhfuil cáilíocht faoi leith acu.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Moynihan Mr. D. Moynihan
Speaker.P: An bhfuil a ndóthain airgid curtha ar fáil don Údarás chun tacaíocht a thabhairt do thionsclóirí atá sásta obair a chur ar fáil sa Ghaeltacht?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Sin ceist eile. Dá mbeadh níos mó airgid dhá chur ar fáil agus dá n-ardófaí an deontas tá mé cinnte go mbeadh dea-thoradh air sin agus go meallfaí níos mó daoine le infheistiú a dhéanamh sa Ghaeltacht. Mar adúirt mé cúpla nóiméad ó shin tá deacrachtaí ann maidir le caiteachas. Tá a fhios sin ag an Teach seo agus b'fhearr liom go mór dá mbeadh níos mó airgid agam le caitheamn sa Ghaeltacht ach níl sé agam.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Moynihan Mr. D. Moynihan
Speaker.P: Nach bhfuil sé fíor go bhfuil tionsclóirí caite uathu ag an Údarás de bharr ganntanas airgid? Nach bhfuil sé fíor go bhfuil tionscloirí ag dul chuig an Údarás atá sásta obair a chur ar fáil do mhuintir na Gaeltachta ach go gcaithfidh siad iad a chaith uathu de bharr gearradh siar ar an airgead?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Níl eolas agam maidir le cás ar bith ar cuireadh tionsclóir nó infheisteoir ó dhoras gan airgead.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - Cúrsaí Samhraidh sa Ghaeltacht.
MainHeading.P: 5. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta cad é an ráta a íocadh le mná tí a chuir lóistín ar fáil do mhic léinn ar na cúrsaí samhraidh sa Ghaeltacht i 1982, 1983, 1984 agus 1985; agus cén t-ardú atá socraithe do 1986.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Seo a leanas na rátaí a íocadh sna blianta a luaitear:

MainHeading.P: Ráta £3.10 in aghaidh an lae a bheidh iníoctha i mbliana.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: Má tá suim ar bith ag an Rialtas seo in athbheocaint na Gaeilge nach ceart go dtabharfadh siad gach cuidiú do mhná tí na Gaeltachta chun cuidiú leis seo? An nglacann an tAire leis nach bhfuil brabach ar bith á dheánamh ag mná tí na Gaeltachta ag deireadh an tSamhraidh? Is é an t-aon bhrabach atá acu go bhfuil a fhios acu go bhfuil na daoine óga seo ag foghlaim na Gaeilge agus go bhfuil siad ag cuidiú le h-athbheocaint na Gaeilge?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Ardaíodh an deontas do na mná tí i 1984 20 faoin gcéad nuair a bhí an ráta boilscithe níos lú ná leath de sin. Ní féidir a rá nach bhfuilimid ag coinneáil suas leis an ráta boilscithe. Má bhreathnaítear ar na figiúirí tá na mná tí ag fáil chúnaimh agus níl siad ag brath air seo amháin. Mar atá a fhios ag an Teachta, níl anseo ach cuid bheag den teacht isteach a fhaigheann siad ó fhoghlaimeoirí na Gaeilge. Tá údaráis na gcoláistí ag bailiú airgid ó thuismitheoirí na bpáistí seo agus cuirtear cuid de seo chuig na mná tí chomh maith. Agus le eolas a thabhairt don Teach maidir le hardú íocaíochtaí — i 1976 bhí £794,000 do na mná tí agus i 1985 bhí £1,110,601 agus tá sin níos mó ná 25 faoin gcéad, agus maidir le h-uimhir na ndaltaí a bhí i gceist is ionann í agus an ráta céanna — 16,400 i gcomparáid le 16,900. Is breá liom é sin a rá mar mura mbeadh na mná tí ann ní bheadh na cúrsaí ann agus ní bheadh foghlaimeoirí Gaeilge ann ach oiread, agus tá súil agam go bhfuil rud éigin acu as anois.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: Níl mná tí na Gaeltachta sásta leis an airgead seo agus tá siad ag insint domsa nach bhfuil siad sásta agus nach bhfuil siad ábalta brath ar na daoine eile ag deireadh an lae agus muna bhfuil an Rialtas sásta ardú reasúnta a thabhairt ní doigh liom go mbeidh na daoine eile sásta ardú reasúnta a thabhairt. Ceapaim féin gur masla é ardú mar seo a thabhairt agus muna bhfuil a fhios ag an Aire b'fhéidir go nglacfadh sé uaimse nach bhfuil na mná tí sásta agus ba chóir don Aire agus don Roinn breathnú iomlán a dhéanamh ar an scéal seo.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Ní raibh a fhios agam go raibh mná tí na Gaeltachta ag clamhsán agus ag gearán. I 1982 ní bhfuair siad pingin rua agus tá mé cinnte go raibh siad ag clamhsán i bhfad níos mó an t-am sin.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: An chéad Cheist eile.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Moynihan Mr. D. Moynihan
Speaker.P: Tá tuismitheoirí ann ar mhaith leo a gcuid leanaí a chur go dtí an Ghaeltacht ach tá sé níos deacra orthu an t-airgead a chur ar fáil chun na mná tí a íoc nó chun na costaisí coláiste a íoc.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: B'fhéidir go bhfuil deacrachtaí ag tuismitheoirí a gcuid páistí a chur go dtí an Ghaeltacht ach níl sé sin le feiceáil sna h-uimhreacha atá ag dul ann. Bhí titim beagán ó 1983 go dtí 1984 ach bhí an-ardú ansin arís anuraidh. Níl a fhios agam. Ní féidir a rá ó na figiúirí atá agamsa anseo go bhfuil deacrachtaí faoi leith ag-tuismitheoirí. Tá na h-uimhreacha ag dul in airde agus sin é an cruthú.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - Fishermen's Training Centres.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Coughlan Mr. Coughlan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Tourism the courses etc. which have been organised for 1986 at the National Training Centre for Fishermen; and if he has any proposals to expand the programme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Tourism (Mr. Kavanagh) Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Tourism (Mr. Kavanagh)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Tourism (Mr. Kavanagh)

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - Fishery Resources.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Taylor Mr. Taylor
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Tourism if he will make a statement on the fishery resources now available; if these are adequate resources in view of the recent accession of Spain and Portugal to the EC; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. H. Byrne Mr. H. Byrne
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Tourism if he will make a statement on the operation of the Common Fisheries Policy since enlargement of the Community; and the additional measures being taken to protect our fisheries since enlargement has taken place.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 8 and 35 together.

I would like to assure the Deputies that the terms enshrined in the Treaty of Accession of Spain and Portugal will ensure that Ireland's vital fisheries interests will be protected in the enlarged Community and that there will be contained scope for further development. The fishing quotas for 1986 negotiated at meetings of the EC Council of Ministers for Fisheries in December last are very satisfactory from our point of view. By comparison with 1985 quotas, the increases secured for 1986 are based on average values worth over £5 million extra.
As the Deputies are aware, responsibility for fisheries protection is proper to the Minister for Defence.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: First, I should like to wish the Minister and the Minister of State well in their new Departments. There is always an element of surprise in fishing but it is very surprising how both Ministers got hooked in this Department. However I wish the Minister well for the few days I hope he will be in office. Is he aware of the widespread anxiety in the industry that enlargement of the Community will mean a sizeable reduction in the amount of financial aid available for modernisation and for restructuring the fleet? Is he aware that the quotas are totally inadequate and that the industry is genuinely depressed, worried and anxious about the present situation? Will he undertake an immediate review of the quota arrangements to see how that matter can be improved and to ensure there will be no loss of revenue in the enlarged Community for development of the fisheries infrastructure?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh
Speaker.P: I thank the Deputy for his kind remarks initially. I would point out that my first position when in Opposition was as spokesman on Fisheries, so this is not a totally new experience for me. The quotas which have been achieved for the present year, even after the enlargement of the Community as a result of the entry of Spain and Portugal, represent an increase of £5 million to the fishermen, which I consider a very good result of the discussions in which my predecessor participated in the December Council. In my new role I will certainly take account of the situation in regard to fishery quotas for Irish fishermen in the months ahead when these come to be discussed again.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - Imported Wood.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McEllistrim Mr. McEllistrim
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Tourism if he is aware of the risk to Irish forests from diseases which can be carried in imported wood; and if he has any proposals to introduce legislation to control the situation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh
Speaker.P: I am fully aware of the risk to Irish forests from pests and diseases which can be carried in imported wood and to this end there are strict plant health controls on imports of certain types of timber and plants. Phyto-sanitary certificates from the country of origin must be presented.

In addition, periodic health surveys of forest areas, especially in the vicinity of sea ports, are carried out. Contingency plans to cope with any reported infection of infestation have been drawn up.

While statutory responsibility for plant health matters is vested in the Minister for Agriculture, my Department as the body responsible for forestry advise the Minister for Agriculture on matters relating to forestry plant health. In addition to the national plant health legislation, regulations are made from time to time by the Minister for Agriculture implementing the provisions of EEC plant health directives.
I am satisfied that the existing legislation, which is kept under constant review, is adequate to meet requirements.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: Would the Minister keep in mind the real danger to the industry here especially from imported timber which still has bark? Is the Minister aware of this and will he examine the situation with a view to introducing some controls?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh
Speaker.P: I am aware of these dangers but as I said in my reply there is good liaison between my Department and the Department of Agriculture to ensure that any infestation arising from importation will be dealt with immediately. Plant health controls are very strict for those types of timber which are liable to bring in this infestation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: The UK authorities recently introduced controls. Will the Minister consider introducing similar precautions here?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh
Speaker.P: I am aware of the controls which have been introduced in Britain since 1982 and I will look at them to see if they can be usefully implemented here.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Walsh Mr. J. Walsh

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - Mayo Piers.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Tourism the amount of money being provided in this year's Estimates for the reconstruction and extension of Darby's Point, County Mayo, and also for Blacksod pier, County Mayo.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh
Speaker.P: The limited funds available for fishery harbour works in the current year have to be applied to the most urgent projects and those on which work has already commenced. In these circumstances it has not been possible to include the reconstruction or extension of Darby's Point or Blacksod pier in this year's programme other than on the provision of navigational lights at Blacksod pier towards which my Department offered Mayo County Council a grant of 75 per cent of the cost.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: Could the Minister accept that in both of these areas the fishing fleets are expanding and that there is grave concern during the peak fishing periods? Will he try to ensure that works will commence as quickly as possible in both of these areas?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh
Speaker.P: I will certainly look at the position to see what can be done in the near future but I want to underline the fact that the limited funds available for this year have already been allocated.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: Can the Minister indicate what stage has been reached in regard to the proposals for the extension of these harbours? Has a survey been carried out and has an estimate of the costs been prepared for the improvement of both harbours?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh
Speaker.P: In January 1984 the West Mayo Fishermen's Co-Operative submitted a modified development scheme for Darby's Point consisting of an extension at right angles to the head of the pier. The Department's engineers have examined the matter and consider that the site and model investigation should be carried out to enable final and practical designs for developments to be drawn up. The Office of Public works have been requested to outline the full scope of the site investigation. It is understood that any costs arising from site investigations this year would be small. Consequently, should any such costs arise they can be carried in the 1986 allocation for harbour development. With regard to Blacksod pier, discussions took place in 1980 between the Department of Fisheries and Forestry, Roinn na Gaeltachta, the OPW and the Fishermen. Roinn na Gaeltachta requested OPW to prepare an engineering report and an estimate of the costs for the following development works at Blacksod pier: firstly, the extension of the pier to give 4ft depth at mean low water; secondly, the provision of leading lights and pier lighting; thirdly, the extension of the pier to give 6ft. depth at mean low water and the provision of a breakwater parallel to the existing pier. In January 1984 Roinn na Gaeltachta forwarded to this Department an engineering report and an estimate in respect of the works mentioned as follows; firstly, to extend the pier by 55 metres to provide four feet at mean low water — £432,000; a working light and an navigation light on the existing pier would cost £3,000; a working light and an navigation light to the extension would cost £2,000; the extension of the pier by 80 metres to provide a 6ft depth, £651,000; breakwater to suit 55-metre extension, £259,000; breakwater to suit an 80-metre extension, £348,000. The minimum cost would have been £693,000 for these. Having examined the report and the cost estimate, it is considered that the expenditure involved could not be justified in view of the landings at Blacksod which were valued at approximately £15,000 in 1983. There is another proposal for an anchorage at Cartron, approximately two miles north of Blacksod, by building a breakwater. A meeting took place in September 1985 with the local fishermen, Roinn na Gaeltachta and the Department to discuss pier improvements also at Blacksod when the fishermen were informed that the original proposed improvements at Blacksod could not be justified, and their views were sought as to the possibility of some alternative improvements such as I have already mentioned.

The modified scheme has been costed and a report on it by the OPW is at present being considered. That report is being examined and assessed in this Department with a view to seeking the sanction of the Department of Finance if its cost is deemed justified on economic grounds. To this end more detailed catch figures have been compiled and these are on record credited to the Blacksod pier and have been challenged by the fishermen. Meanwhile this Department in the interests of safety have offered Mayo a grant of 75 per cent of the cost of providing urgently required working navigational lights which are part of the modified scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: Do I take if from the Minister's reply that there appears to be no possibility of having any money spent on either pier?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh
Speaker.P: I have given the Deputy the full information I have. At present there seems to be an amount of money to provide navigational lights only, particularly since the value of the catch, as I have told the Deputy, was the very low sum of £15,000 in 1983. Should the figure have improved substantially I imagine we can reinvestigate the situation.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - Regional Game Councils.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kitt Mr. Kitt
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Tourism the increase in grant-in-aid to the regional game councils over the last three years; and if he will increase the amount this year.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh
Speaker.P: No grants have been paid by my Department to regional game councils since 1982. A grant of £10,000 was paid to the National Association of Regional Game Councils in each of the years 1984 and 1985. There is no provision in the Revised Estimates of Public Expenditure for 1986 for the payment of a similar grant this year and the association have been informed accordingly.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - Aid to Fishermen.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Browne Mr. Browne
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Tourism the amount of additional aid which was paid to enable fishermen to meet loan repayments in 1985; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh
Speaker.P: The main elements of the aid package which came into operation on 1 July 1985 were — (a) Capitalisation of arrears; (b) Extension of repayment period; (c) Transfer from straight line to annuity system of loan repayment; (d) Increased level of interest subsidy.

The elements at (a), (b) and (c) above in relation to the restructuring of accounts meant that in some cases a considerable reduction in the annual repayments by fishermen but it is not possible to put a cash value on this aid. The improved interest subsidy provided for a minimum net interest rate of 9 per cent and was estimated to cost £300,000 in a full year. Because, however, of the fall in interest rates in 1985 the estimated additional cost for the six months in which the revised rates applied was of the order of £100,000.

The package also included the total remission of the excise duty on fuel oil for fishing vessels at an estimated cost of £0.5 million and provided for an additional sum of £480,000 for marketing and exploratory fishing with a view to improving fishermen's incomes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: Would the Minister accept that, while any aid to fishermen is accepted gratefully by them, this was not direct aid as such, that this aid was taken from other grants-in-aid which should have gone to BIM for other purposes? Would he accept also that this grant aid is available only to those who obtain grants from BIM and that many people in the fishing industry have secured grants from other financial institutions and through other channels? When he gets an opportunity to study this, will he consider giving an opportunity to those people to obtain some relief from the various heavy overheads which they have?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh
Speaker.P: I am glad the Deputy accepts that the aids which were in the package were of benefit to many fishermen. If he tells me that there are others who could benefit from a similar package we will look at that situation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: Could the Minister give any indication of the number who benefited from it? As we all know, it was mainly a readjustment of existing finances and the amount spent was very small.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh
Speaker.P: No, I have not got that information.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - Joint Committee on Game Management.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Tourism the functions of the Joint Committee on Game Management, the members and organisations represented thereon; if he will give all relevant details on their brief; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh
Speaker.P: The Joint Committee on Game Development was established in 1966 with the aim of realising the full potential of tourist shooting by assisting in the development of tourist shoots, promoting and marketing them and giving grants to private promoters. The committee comprise officials of the Forest and Wildlife Service of my Department and Bord Fáilte. The committee meet periodically — on average about three times a year over the past five years. I am having the future role of the committee re-examined at present.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: Can the Minister give us any indication of the amount of money spent by the committee?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh
Speaker.P: No, I was not asked for that information and I have not got it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: Is it big or small?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh
Speaker.P: I gave the grants they got.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: What is their expenditure? What is their budget?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh
Speaker.P: All I can give is what I was asked for and that is the grants made available to them.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: How much is that?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh
Speaker.P: I will tell the Deputy again. Total grants in the order of £10,000 per annum were provided over a period of 15 years. They were withdrawn in 1982. That was the position.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - County Cork Lands Sale.

Speaker.hpid: Miss M. Barry Miss M. Barry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Tourism the reason for the delay on the part of his Department in calling to see a person (details supplied) in respect of the sale of lands in County Cork.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh
Speaker.P: While my Department aim to respond as quickly as possible to persons offering to sell land to them for afforestation, in present circumstances delays can occasionally occur in individual cases depending on the number of offers received in a particular period and the availability of staff to deal with them. In the present case an inspector of the Department called on the person named, in November last, but failed to contact him. He called again in January and having inspected the lands, has reached agreement with him for their purchase by the Department.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - Private Investment in Afforestation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kirk Mr. Kirk
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Tourism when he will introduce a plan of action to encourage private investment in afforestation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh
Speaker.P: It is the Government's policy to encourage private investment in afforestation in harmony with the State forestry programme. To this end there are generous planting grants available and my Department also provide a free technical advisory service covering all aspects of afforestation.

A special publicity campaign was launched in October 1985 to promote private forestry generally and highlighted the favourable rates of afforestation grants available under the forestry elements of the western package. The campaign led to a substantial increase in the number of requests received for information and technical advice by potential private investors. There is every indication that there will be a substantial increase in planting in 1986 and subsequent years.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kirk Mr. Kirk
Speaker.P: Having regard to the great disparity between the level of grant aid in the 12 western counties and the rest of the country, the prospect of encouraging people in counties outside the 12 western counties to invest in private afforestation is very slim; the chances of them investing their money in private afforestation are very slim. Does the Minister not think the time has arrived when the level of grant aid which applies in the western package area should apply to the country as a whole? I have in mind the Cooley area in north Louth which is on the Border with south Armagh and south Down. Much of the soil there is suitable for afforestation. However, because the level of grant aid available in the county is not sufficiently attractive, people are not prepared to invest. Yet a mere few miles away in County Monaghan, which happens to be in the western package area, there is a much more generous grant scheme in operation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh
Speaker.P: I would have some sympathy with the Deputy's point of view, as I represent a county which is not within the western package area and which has a large forestry acreage. This encouragement is given under the western package and, in order to expand that scheme to other areas, there would have to be negotiations. The western package would have to be extended beyond the present 12 counties and that would have to be done in conjunction with the EC. I should certainly like to see it extended perhaps to the agricultural disadvantaged areas. It would be in the interests of everybody if that could be done. I hope we can have discussions with the EC on the matter in the coming year, to see if we can achieve an extension of the package.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kirk Mr. Kirk
Speaker.P: Do I take it from that, that the Minister is going to pursue actively the matter of ensuring that the western package level of grant aid will be available in the rest of the country? The validity of my argument is such that it is imperative that this matter be pursued immediately.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh
Speaker.P: As I said, I am aware of areas outside the western package area which would immediately benefit from an encouraged investment in afforestation. As the Deputy knows, the county from which I come could certainly benefit if the western package were extended to include it. We are both in the same position on this matter and I hope he will accept my assurance that it would be in all our interests to see if we can get that extension.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: Before the Ceann Comhairle moves to priority questions, with the Minister's permission and that of my colleagues, may I be allowed to ask Question No. 18, or are there statutory regulations preventing me from doing this?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: There is an order of the House directing me in that regard.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: Far be it from me to interfere with the Chair on this.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I am moving to questions nominated for priority.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - Salmon Fishing Controls.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Tourism if he will make a statement on the position regarding salmon fishing controls in 1986; if he is proposing any changes in salmon fishing controls; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh
Speaker.P: The various controls on salmon fishing which operated in 1985 are ongoing and will continue to apply in 1986. The nature and extent of these controls are kept under continuous review and may be altered at any time to meet changing circumstances.
The White Paper on the fishing industry which will be published shortly will outline the Government's future policy in relation to salmon fishing and conservation measures.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: The Minister will be aware that by order he designates the number of licences which can be issued in any fishing year. Has the Minister made any changes in the order for 1985? May I have some indication of the total number of drift net licences for the 1986 season?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh
Speaker.P: I have made no changes at this stage in the number of licences. I have not even considered it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: Could I have some indication as to whether it is the Minister's intention to look at the orders and if he has any proposals in mind at this stage to review the licences for the different fishery board areas? He will be aware that the fishing season is about to get under way and if he is to make any changes in this regard he would certainly need to do so now.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh
Speaker.P: As I said, I intend to continue the controls which existed in 1985. However, I also intend to keep a continuous review of this situation. At this stage I have not had the opportunity to look into the matter but I can see that a review might be necessary. However, I cannot envisage any great change from what has been occurring over the last few years.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: The Minister will be aware of the continuing decline in the salmon stocks, in particular, and that various regional fishery boards have been very vocal in complaining of the lack of adequate finances to enable them to carry out their statutory responsibilities. Would the Minister keep in mind, in any review which may be undertaken, that it is essential at a very early stage that adequate finances be made available to the regional salmon fishery boards to enable them to fulfil their statutory obligations? He will be aware that at present boards in every area are complaining that they do not have either the manpower or the resources to enable them to protect the salmon stocks which are now in very real danger. Could I bring this matter to the attention of the Minister and ask him to take action as soon as possible?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh
Speaker.P: I cannot judge, from what the Deputy is saying, whether he considers the present controls to be too lax or too stringent. Perhaps he would indicate in which direction he would prefer me to move.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: People would be more interested in what action the Minister will take and what direction he will be taking in the area of salmon conservation, bearing in mind that salmon stocks are now in danger. It is essential that the fishery boards who have a statutory obligation to protect the salmon fisheries should be in a position to do this. They are not because they totally lack the necessary finances. Could the Minister keep it in mind that the boards are now in total disarray? They cannot hold meetings because of a lack of finance to enable them to carry out their obligations.

MainHeading.P: Would he keep in mind that every board is in a very serious financial situation?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kavanagh Mr. Kavanagh
Speaker.P: I shall keep the Deputy's comments in mind. I think I can interpret them as an appeal for stricter conservation measures, nevertheless.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - Comhaltas Ceoltóirí Éireann.
MainHeading.P: 40. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta ó tharla an oiread sin tábhacht a bheith leis an obair atá ar siúl ag Comhaltas Ceoltóirí Éireann lenár gceol agus ár gcultúr a neartú, an mbeadh sé sásta deontas breise a chur ar fáil dóibh i mbliana lena gcuid oibre a neartú.

Speaker.hpid: Aire na Gaeltachta (Mr. O'Toole) Aire na Gaeltachta (Mr. O'Toole)
Speaker.P: Tá socraithe an deontas bliantúil a íocann mo Roinnse le Comhaltas Ceoltóirí Éireann a mhéadú ó £120,000 i 1985 go £125,000 i mbliana.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: Ó tharla gur obair an-tábhachtach atá á déanamh ag Comhaltas Ceoltóirí Éireann chun ár gceol agus ár gcultúr a chur chun cinn, agus ó tharla go bhfuil siad ag cailleadh deontas £60,000 a bhí á fháil acu ón Chomhairle Ealaíne, an nglacfadh an tAire leis nach mbeidh morán buntáiste san ardú atá luaite aige — séard a bheidh ann ná cailliúint san méid airgid a bheidh le fáil acu ón Stát i mbliana, cé go bhfuil an obair atá á déanamh acu ag dul i méid agus ag éirigh níos tábhachtaí in aghaidh an lae.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Tá méadú árd tagtha i ndeontas na bliana seo i gcomparáid leis an deontas a fuair siad i 1985. Cuir i gcás, i 1983 fuair siad £179,129 in iomlán ó chuile fhoinse; i 1984, fuair siad £512,143, agus i gcomhthéacs leis sin fuair siad £300,000 ó Chiste na nAgróirí, agus aontóidh an Teach leis an iocaíocht sin; agus anuraidh fuair siad £231,975. Má bhreathnaíonn an Teach air sin mar iomlán feicfidh sé gur deontas an-ard é sin. Thagraigh an Teachta don Chomhairle Ealaíne. Níl aon smacht agamsa ar cén cinneadh atá ar intinn ag an gComhairle Ealaíne maidir le deontas a chur ar fáil d'aon eagras i mbliana.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: Ní ceart don Aire bheith ag iarraidh dallamullóg a chur ar an Teach le figiúirí. Táimid ag caint faoi chostais reatha, caiteachas atá ag an gcomhaltas le haghaidh na bliana. I measc na bhfigiúirí sin tá costais chaipitiúil — airgead a fuair siad chun an amharclann a dheisiú. Tá a lán caiteachais acu; cuireann siad amach céirníní, agus tá obair an-mhaith ar siúl acu. Séard atá luaite ag an Aire ná caiteachas bliantúil, agus níl sé sin sasúil.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Tá an ceart ag an Teachta nuair a deireann sé go bhfuil fadhbanna airgid ag an gcomhaltas. Go bunúsach, is fadhbanna caipitiúla iad. Tá siad ag iarraidh cultúrlann agus amharclann a thógáil. Tá mé ag rá, agus dúirt mé é go poiblí cheana, gur thóg siad na fiacha seo orthu féin in aghaidh mo chomhairle agus comhairle Roinn na Gaeltachta. Cuireadh ina luí orthu ag an am go raibh siad ag tnú le suimeanna airgid nach mbeifí ábalta teacht orthu. Níor ghlacadh leis an chomhairle sin agus bhí siad i dtrioblóid. Cuireadh £300,000 ar fáil dóibh ó Chiste na nAgróirí agus chuir sé sin moill ar a gcuid deacrachtaí beagán, ach tá fadhbanna acu. Glacaim leis go bhfuil obair an-tábhachtach á déanamh acu, ach dar ndóigh is fadhbanna caipitiúla atá i gceist, ní fadhbanna airgid reatha.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: An nglacfadh an tAire nach bhfuil sé sasúil go mbeadh ar an Chomhaltas daoine a dí-fhostú, nach mbeidh siad in ann comhairle a thabhairt do Bhord Fáilte i mbliana ná do na hambasáidí maidir le cultúr agus ceol ár dtíre, agus nach mbeidh siad in ann dul ar aghaidh leis an National Entertainments Scheme faoin a raibh 45 ionad in a raibh na scéimeanna sin ar fáil iontu? Turasóirí is mó a bhaineann usáid as na hionáid seo. An nglacann an tAire nach bhfuil sé sásúil nach mbeidh comhaltas in ann na scéimeanna sin a chur ar aghaidh i mbliana ar mhaithe le turasóireacht agus leis an tír ar fad?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Níl a fhios agam céard atá ar intinn acu maidir le scéimeanna a chur ar fáil tríd an tír. Séard tá a rá agam ná go bhfuil ardú á thabhairt agamsa dóibh, ar aon chéim le ráta boilscithe na bliana seo. Má tá ganntanas airgid orthu ní féidir an mhéar a shíneadh chugamsa.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: Nach bhfuil áit faoi leith don Aire agus do Roinn na Gaeltachta sna cúrsaí seo? Más rud é nach bhfuil an Chomhairle Ealaíne ag cur airgid ar fáil i mbliana don chomhaltas, nach bhfuil sé de dhualgas ar an Aire a chinntiú go mbeidh níos mó le fáil acu i mbliana ar mhaithe le turasóireacht agus cúrsaí cultúrtha go ginearálta.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Tá ardú tugtha agamsa, agus má tá ballraíocht an chomhaltais chomh hard agus a deirtear — agus glacaim go bhfuil an bhallraíocht ard — tá mé cinnte go bhféadfar teacht ar shocrú chun táillí a bhailiú ón bhallraíocht chun airgead a sholáthar don chomhaltas.

MainHeading.Title: Private Notice Questions. - Sellafield Nuclear Plant.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach if he will make an urgent request to the British Government to close down the nuclear plant at Sellafield.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach, if in view of the serious public concern about the number of incidents at the Sellafield Nuclear Reprocessing Plant in Britain involving leaks of radioactive material and the evidence that British Nuclear Fuels have on a number of occasions given misleading and inaccurate information about incidents at the plant, he will indicate the measures the Government are taking to ensure the health and safety of Irish citizens is not endangered; pending discussions with the British Government on the future of the plant, if he will request the British authorities to agree to the appointment of an observer nominated by the British Government to be based in Sellafield and to monitor and report on all incidents there and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I intend to take the two questions together. It is appropriate that I should say how disturbed the Government have been, and continue to be, about the entire situation.

I intend to raise these concerns at a meeting which I am having with the British Prime Minister tomorrow and I would intend to convey to her that the number of incidents, notwithstanding that they may be described as being of negligible radiological significance, has caused a loss of confidence in Ireland in the safety of the reprocessing of nuclear materials at Sellafield. This loss of confidence has been heightened by the disclosure in The Sunday Times of 16 February 1985 that discharges from Sellafield which took place in 1953-55 may have been 40 times higher than those made available for the Black report.

In the light of all this, I will be urging the British Prime Minister that there should be a thorough review of safety procedures at the Sellafield plant. I intend also to seek ministerial discussions in Brussels with a view to proposing a European inspection force which would monitor activities such as those at Sellafield.

In recent years this Government, through the contact group established with the UK, and by other means, have taken steps designed to ensure that we would be kept abreast of all developments at Sellafield. But because of my dissatisfaction with the information we have been given, it is my intention to seek a full meeting of officials of all relevant Departments and bodies in the UK and in the Republic. I consider that this would contribute to greater cohesion in the prompt receipt of the information being made available. I see this as a necessary improvement to the working of the contact group established by Irish and UK Ministers in 1984.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: At his meeting with the British Prime Minister tomorrow, will the Taoiseach convey to her the deep anxiety felt throughout Ireland at the continuing existence of this potentially deadly menace, and the widespread anger and resentment that exist here because of the many false statements made, bogus reassurances given and the cover up engaged in by the British authorities in this matter?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: As I have said, I will convey to the British Prime Minister that the number of incidents have caused loss of confidence in Ireland in the safety of the reprocessing plant at Sellafield, and this has been heightened by the information now available that earlier figures given were incorrect. We have been concerned also that the initial information given in respect of an incidents of 5 February 1986 turned out to be incorrect. The fact that in these two incidents in particular the information made available initially — in one case the information was allowed to stand for a long period — proved to be incorrect gives particular cause for concern. We were not promptly and fully informed of what actually had been happening at Sellafield.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Does the Taoiseach not recall that the Tánaiste, following a meeting with British Ministers and officials in London regarding Sellafield safety in February 1984 said that he was particularly satisfied with the talks and that Mr. Jenkins had reassured him that an incident such as last year's could not happen again? Will the Taoiseach now admit that these assurances, like all the similar assurances which followed, were worthless and that the Tánaiste was naive to the point of negligence in accepting them?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I do not accept that. The position is that the information available to us, and it may well be available to the British Government also, was incomplete.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: That is no excuse.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: That is now clear and it is a matter of concern that we should ensure against repetition of that. It is for that reason that I intend, inter alia, seeking Ministerial discussions in Brussels with a view to proposing a European inspection force to monitor activities such as those at Sellafield.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: Will the Taoiseach not accept the proposal I put forward in relation to the appointment of an Irish Government observer at Sellafield? Will the Taoiseach indicate if he is aware that Dr. Black, an Irish scientist, has indicated that in his view the only way to make Sellafield safe is to have it shut down? Will the Taoiseach comment on the view expressed by Dr. Nolan of the Irish Nuclear Energy Board that reports from the nuclear installation inspectorate in Britain are not being made available to him promptly or in any detail?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: As I have said, the question of the availability of information is something that concerns us. That is why I am seeking a full meeting of officials of all relevant Departments and bodies in the UK and the Republic, because I am not convinced that the information coming separately from different sources at present is giving a coherent picture or that we are getting the information as rapidly as we should.

On the Deputy's first point, I have to say that the question as it reached me proposed an observer nominated by the British Government, not the Irish Government. It was only when the Deputy read out his question that I learned that it was an Irish Government observer he was proposing. That seems to me to be a more reasonable proposal than the one I received in writing. In fact, I believe this is a matter that could better be dealt with, if we can achieve that, through a European inspection force. That is a matter that we will be raising in the first instance in Brussels.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Does the Taoiseach recall that when I called in July 1984 for the closure of Sellafield and the imprisonment of those responsible for running the plant I was accused by the then Minister for the Environment, Deputy Kavanagh, of indulging in alarmist questioning? Does the Taoiseach further recall that the Minister of State at the Department of Energy, Deputy Eddie Collins, accused me of indulging in alarming questioning on 22 January 1985 and stated that there was no danger to people living in Ireland from discharges from Sellafield? Will the Taoiseach now ask the Ministers to withdraw their statements, admit they were wrong and apologise to the Irish people for their negligent behaviour?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Kennedy Mr. O'Kennedy
Speaker.P: Or fire them.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I have to point out that, while we are concerned about the discharges, concerned that there have been a number of incidents there, concerned that within a period of three weeks there have been three incidents which is a very high rate of occurrence of incidents——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Too late.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: ——and concerned about the flow and accuracy of information, nonetheless the monitoring being carried out here, both in respect of marine life and of the atmosphere, indicate that the level of discharges that reach this country is at a very low level indeed. I believe I am right in saying that it is under 1 per cent of the safety margin. I do not accept what the Deputy has said, but the fact that that is the result of our own monitoring of the air and sea pollution does not mean that we can be satisfied with a situation in which incidents have occurred with such frequency and in which the information available has turned out to be correct. That is why the matter has to be pursued further.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Will the Taoiseach now admit that his Government and Ministers have been grossly negligent in their handling of this issue, firstly pretending that there was no problem at all regarding Sellafield and then accepting worthless assurances in regard to it and now, even at this late stage, leaving the matter to be dealt with by a rather incompetent junior Minister? Will the Taoiseach not accept the view from this side of the House that the only safe way of dealing with this matter from the point of view of the Irish people is to close this menace and close it forthwith?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I do not accept any of the Deputy's earlier statements. With regard to the closure of Sellafield, that is a situation that could arise in the light of the monitoring procedures which we propose.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: The only monitoring the Taoiseach has is The Sunday Times.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I am referring to the monitoring procedure I have taken up in Brussels through the Council of Ministers there.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: As Head of the Irish Government will the Taoiseach not now take the necessary steps to protect the Irish people from this danger which is no longer problematic but certain? Is the Taoiseach prepared to stand up to the British Government on this matter or is he now completely in their pocket?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Farrelly Mr. Farrelly
Speaker.P: Shame on Deputy Haughey.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. O'Keeffe Mr. E. O'Keeffe
Speaker.P: Hand it all over to Barry.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Flippancy from that side will not get them off on this one.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lenihan Mr. Lenihan
Speaker.P: Or telling lies about the issue.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: I should like to ask the Taoiseach a question about the funding of the Nuclear Energy Board, which, it is alleged, is underfinanced and, therefore, is being restricted in its ability to monitor the effects of radioactivity in the Irish Sea, in the atmosphere and along our coasts.

Will the Taoiseach indicate if it is proposed to increase the funding to the NEB to make their monitoring more effective? Will the Taoiseach clarify for me his reference to the possibility of a European observer in Sellafield? The Taoiseach made that statement in response to my request that an Irish observer should be appointed by the Irish Government for Sellafield.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I had difficulty hearing the last part of the Deputy's question.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: I suggested that the Irish Government should have an observer resident at Sellafield and, in response to that, the Taoiseach indicated that he hoped to achieve this by having a European observer appointed. Will the Taoiseach clarify what he meant by that?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: What I had in mind was that a European inspection force should be available to monitor activities such as those at Sellafield but not necessarily only Sellafield. The Deputy will appreciate that the question as put down proposed a British Government observer which did not seem to me to be a particularly satisfactory way of dealing with the problem. That did not seem to be a particularly useful way to attack this. It seemed to me that it would be better to look for a European inspection force which could draw on a wide range of expertise, could take a wider view and give us reliable guidance to problems that might arise. That seems to me to be the best way to proceed at this stage.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Problems have arisen.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I will allow Deputy De Rossa ask a further supplementary to be followed by Deputy Gerard Brady, because he has been taking an interest in this.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: I must take issue with the Taoiseach on this matter of a European inspectorate. Inspections up to now have been inadequate and what is required is an Irish presence pending a decision on what is to be done with the installation. There is a need for an Irish presence at Sellafield to constantly monitor what is going on.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: He would be contaminated.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: I am asking the Taoiseach to press for that.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: As I was not aware that that was the point the Deputy was raising, I would have to reflect on it. I do not exclude it, but it seemed to me that a European monitoring force would be better than having a British observer. I will reflect on the point the Deputy has made now that I understand the point he is trying to get at.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Brady Mr. G. Brady
Speaker.P: In the light of the little understood fact that British Nuclear Fuels have an expansion plan for Sellafield of the order of £2 billion and that 20 to 30 monthly shipments of nuclear fuel traverse the Irish Sea, may I raise the matter on the Adjournment?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That concludes Question Time.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: I wish to raise on the Adjournment——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I thought Deputy Brady was asking a question. Otherwise I would not have called him.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Brady Mr. G. Brady
Speaker.P: I was asking a question.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That is all right. I will allow Deputy O'Leary to put his question later. I have received notice from the Taoiseach that he wishes to make an announcement.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: In the absence of resignations in writing, the Government today terminated the appointments as Ministers of State of Deputies Michael D'Arcy and Donal Creed. Accordingly, the appointments of Deputy Enda Kenny and Deputy Avril Doyle as Ministers of State take effect from today's date. I regret that I informed the House on Thursday last that the two Deputies had resigned.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: I wish to ask a question.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I shall allow one question from Deputy Haughey.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: I deplore the fact that these important matters are being dealt with unilaterally and by way of announcement. That is in breach of the traditions and precedents of this House.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I have said that I am allowing Deputy Haughey to ask a question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. L'Estrange Mr. L'Estrange
Speaker.P: What about Deputy Haughey refusing in 1970 to resign when requested to do so by Mr. Lynch?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: In view of the untrue version the Taoiseach gave on television of the removal or otherwise of Deputy Barry Desmond from the Department of Health and in view also of his admission here today that he told the Dáil an untruth on Thursday last, will he now consider his own position?

Speaker.hpid: Deputies Deputies
Speaker.P: Hear, hear.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I simply wish to rebut these allegations.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: The Taoiseach told the House an untruth.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: It is proposed to take Nos. 4, 5, 6 and 22. Private Members' Business will be No. 46.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Can the Taoiseach say if it is now the position that the Government reluctantly, and having been dragged into doing so, propose to allow time for a two-day debate Thursday and Friday of this week — to consider a very well justified motion of no confidence?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: The Government are prepared to allow a two-day debate. Originally we offered a one day debate and I understand that was accepted but subsequently the Opposition changed their minds.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: A one day debate was not accepted.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: In the light of their having changed their minds we accept their latest view.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: The Taoiseach should tell the truth.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Order, please.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lenihan Mr. Lenihan
Speaker.P: He will not be able to tell lies in Madame Tussauds.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Waxy Taoiseach.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: I wish to raise on the Adjournment the decision of the Minister for Education to close down the Cappanalea outdoor education centre in Killorglin, County Kerry with effect from 28 February.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Chair will communicate with the Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. McCarthy Dr. McCarthy
Speaker.P: On a point of order, will the Taoiseach confirm the claim of Deputy Creed, as reported in yesterday's Cork Examiner, that the Taoiseach told a lie in the House on Thursday last and thereby misled the House?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That is not a point of order.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. McCarthy Dr. McCarthy
Speaker.P: Will the Taoiseach confirm whether Deputy Creed was correct in that statement?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Deputy is not in order. He will have an opportunity to raise such matters on Thursday and Friday.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. McCarthy Dr. McCarthy
Speaker.P: Is the Taoiseach prepared to confirm that Deputy Creed told the truth when he said that the Taoiseach told lies?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Deputy must resume his seat.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Order, please.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McGahon Mr. McGahon
Speaker.P: The Deputy should take a valium.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I must intervene at this stage in regard to the word “lie” in all its forms. I listened carefully to the remarks of Deputy Haughey in regard to the words, “lie” and “untruth”. The words used by the Deputy were in order and within the precedents of the House but I get the impression that that seems to be taken as a licence to use the term “lie” freely and to use it also in all its shapes and forms.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Order, please. The Chair should be given the respect of a hearing. I have the book of precedents here and these go back to the foundation of the State. There are approximately two pages of these precedents all of which make it perfectly clear that an allegation that a person is telling a lie is not in order. I have had this book here for some considerable time and I will summarise the ruling in regard to that word. It is that the use of the word “lie” or words which imply a lie cannot be allowed, that otherwise the conduct of debate in an orderly and dignified way would become an impossibility. That is the position and I am now calling for order.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. McCarthy Dr. McCarthy
Speaker.P: On a point of order, I am merely asking the Taoiseach ——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Deputy is not in order in asking any question.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. McCarthy Dr. McCarthy
Speaker.P: You are presuming to know what the question is.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: We know the Deputy is a gurrier.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. McCarthy Dr. McCarthy
Speaker.P: I did not make any allegation in regard to lies. I am only asking the Taoiseach if he is prepared to confirm what one of his own colleagues is reported as saying, that is that the Taoiseach told lies.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Deputy is not in order. He will resume his seat quickly.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: You referred to the book of precedents and said that these precedents go back to the foundation of the State but on a point of order may I ask if there is any precedent in that book for a Taoiseach coming here on a Thursday evening to make a statement and then a few days later having to come back and say he misled the House?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That is not in order.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: On the basis of what we have heard here today we ought to know whether there is any such precedent.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. O'Keeffe Mr. E. O'Keeffe
Speaker.P: I wish to raise on the Adjournment the matter of the continuing deplorable delays in the carrying out of inspections throughout the country for the purpose of the housing reconstruction grants.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Chair will communicate with the Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Sheehan Mr. Sheehan
Speaker.P: There are plenty of applications being dealt with in my constituency.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. McCarthy Dr. McCarthy
Speaker.P: The Deputy should go back to his gombeen men.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Sheehan Mr. Sheehan
Speaker.P: There are no gombeen men in west Cork, only true Irishmen.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. O'Keeffe Mr. E. O'Keeffe
Speaker.P: What are the Government doing with the £40 million that was intended for Bantry.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Sheehan Mr. Sheehan
Speaker.P: What did the Deputy's party ever give to Bantry?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I am appealing to Deputies on all sides to behave themselves and to allow the business of the House to continue.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Kennedy Mr. O'Kennedy
Speaker.P: Could I once again ask the Taoiseach or the Minister for the time being responsible when we will have the Book of Estimates to enable us to adhere to proper procedure in the House? I would impress on the Chair, particularly today, in view of the fact that unless we do other Ministers face the risk of summary execution like their colleaguse who have gone into——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Deputy O'Kennedy, please, I have allowed the question——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Kennedy Mr. O'Kennedy
Speaker.P: It is vitally important.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: ——but I cannot allow a speech.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Kennedy Mr. O'Kennedy
Speaker.P: Two Ministers have been fired——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Deputy O'Kennedy is one of the greatest offenders against Standing Orders in this House.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Kennedy Mr. O'Kennedy
Speaker.P: Would the Taoiseach please tell us when we will get the Book of Estimates?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: There is no change in normal procedures under which where changes in the Estimates announced in the budget to the Book of Estimates are advised and prepared, and they will be made available as soon as possible. The Deputy is well aware of precedent.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Kennedy Mr. O'Kennedy
Speaker.P: I want to pursue that.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: You cannot, Deputy. The Deputy may pursue it in the budget debate.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Kennedy Mr. O'Kennedy
Speaker.P: I am talking about the order.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Deputy O'Kennedy will resume his seat.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Kennedy Mr. O'Kennedy
Speaker.P: On a point of order.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Item No. 22. Deputy Hilliard is in possession and has 57 minutes left.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Hilliard Mr. Hilliard
Speaker.P: I may want extra time.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Deputy has almost an hour.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Hilliard Mr. Hilliard
Speaker.P: I find it very difficult as a member of the Opposition to contribute to a budget debate when the budget was introduced by a different Minister for Finance and especially when the Taoiseach misled this House with the recent juggling of the Cabinet. It is strange to have a different Minister for Finance taking the budget through the Dáil now.

MainHeading.P: This budget has done little or nothing to give our people hope. It is obvious that the people want a change of Government. It is wrong for the Government to stay in office seeing that the people have no confidence in them. There must be confidence in any successful business, and Government is a business, if its policies are to be successful. The longer such a Government stays in office the more cautious harm will be done to the economy. People are becoming more cautious about investing money here at home. The Government have done nothing to improve the situation with this budget. There is no encouragement for business or farming enterprises to expand and there is no encouragement for workers to work harder or to create extra employment. It is sad to have able and willing people on the dole, people who want to work and cannot get work. Family life is being seriously affected by this. It is sad that so many educated young people must emigrate. Most people want to do something worthwhile with their lives but unfortunately many cannot find employment here and must emigrate. Boredom can be very harmful to society so it is important that we properly equip those who have to emigrate.

This budget will not maintain or increase our economic growth. Without economic growth we cannot create the revenue to provide the services. We cannot demand more from the taxpayers. Taxpayers' money should be invested in new productive areas and in areas which have been successful but which need increased investment if we are to create the urgently needed extra revenue required. There is no sense in continuing to spend more of taxpayers' money direct on administration and services when we cannot afford to do so. The money generated from productivity should be reinvested in productive areas a second time and this should be the priority of any Government at present.
